title: The Platinum Yendorian Express Card
data:
| (   The Platinum Yendorian Express Card   *(No tile)* |                                                                                                                                                                               |
| ----------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Base item                                             | [credit card](/wiki/Credit_card "Credit card")                                                                                                                                |
|                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                               |
| Affiliation                                           | - [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral")
- [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist")
- [intelligent](/wiki/Intelligent_artifacts "Intelligent artifacts")                                |
|                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                               |
| When carried                                          | * [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy")
* [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance")
* [half spell damage](/wiki/Half_spell_damage "Half spell damage") |
| When applied                                          | *(none)*                                                                                                                                                                      |
| When invoked                                          | - [charging](/wiki/Charging "Charging")                                                                                                                                       |
|                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                               |
| Base price                                            | 7000 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")                                                                                                                                            |
| Weight                                                | [1](/wiki/Weight "Weight")                                                                                                                                                    |

**The Platinum Yendorian Express Card**, informally **PYEC**, is the [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist") [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact"). It is the prize for completing the [Tourist quest](/wiki/Tourist_quest "Tourist quest"), and is [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") for [wishing](/wiki/Wish "Wish") purposes. Its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") type is a [credit card](/wiki/Credit_card "Credit card").

The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is the only vanilla quest [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") whose name is not of the form *“The X of \[the] Y.”*

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
  - [3.1 Conducts](#Conducts)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.3 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [6.4 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.5 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

For Tourists, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is always guarded by the [Master of Thieves](/wiki/Master_of_Thieves "Master of Thieves"), and is placed on his square in the northwestern-most room of the Tourist quest goal level.

If the artifact is generated in a [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") file that is discovered by a Tourist, it will always be replaced with its mundane base item.

## Description

While carried, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card confers [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance"), [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy") and [half spell damage](/wiki/Half_spell_damage "Half spell damage"). [Invoking](/wiki/Invoking "Invoking") the Card can [charge](/wiki/Charge "Charge") objects like a [scroll of charging](/wiki/Scroll_of_charging "Scroll of charging"), with different effects based on the Card's beatitude: Tourists can invoke the blessed Platinum Yendorian Express Card to charge objects in the same way as a blessed scroll of charging, while the artifact only charges like an uncursed scroll for non-Tourists.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Unlike the scroll, the Card has no special effect if invoked while you are [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused").

## Strategy

- *Main article: [Invoke#Optimal invocation schedule](/wiki/Invoke#Optimal_invocation_schedule "Invoke")*

The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is considered one of the best artifacts in the game due to its unique invoke, incredibly light weight and valuable properties, making it an enticing and somewhat common artifact [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for neutral players - be sure that you can survive the ensuing [artifact blast](/wiki/Artifact_blast "Artifact blast"), and wish for it [fireproofed](/wiki/Fireproof "Fireproof")! The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is a powerful aid for various purposes, such as [altar farming](/wiki/Altar_farming "Altar farming") using a [bag of tricks](/wiki/Bag_of_tricks "Bag of tricks") or [wand of create monster](/wiki/Wand_of_create_monster "Wand of create monster"), or [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling") for certain weapons and/or magical tools - players [eating jewelry](/wiki/Eating_jewelry "Eating jewelry") often use the Card to charge any applicable rings.

Tourists completing their [Quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") are in a particularly good position, as the [Master of Thieves](/wiki/Master_of_Thieves "Master of Thieves") lacks any other resistances beyond [stoning resistance](/wiki/Stoning_resistance "Stoning resistance") and the magic resistance from picking up the Card, making him one of the easier nemeses to defeat. Tourists also get the most out of the artifact by far, and can use blessed charging from the Card's invoke to efficiently recharge their [wand of wishing](/wiki/Wand_of_wishing "Wand of wishing") or [magic markers](/wiki/Magic_marker "Magic marker") where any other role would require a blessed scroll of charging.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) The artifact also grants more mileage from various wands and certain stat-boosting rings, as well as practically-infinite use of charged tools, without using scrolls or marker charges; this makes uncursed charging and [artifact blasts](/wiki/Artifact_blast "Artifact blast") worth dealing with for non-Tourists far more often than not, and can save a lot of inventory space for the weight-conscious player.

With all the above perks in mind, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is a luxury for neutral non-Tourists (albeit an excellent one): they should prioritize wishes that increase survivability where possible, though lucky players (especially ones that get early wishes) may find themselves with a spare wish that can be spent on the Card if so desired. Any role using the Card should have other sources of magic resistance and telepathy available alongside the Card—the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") can swipe it from you with his [Amulet](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor")-targeting attack and becomes far more troublesome to deal with if he does, so it is typically a good idea to [bag](/wiki/Bag "Bag") it during the late game and [ascension run](/wiki/Ascension_run "Ascension run").

### Conducts

[Neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") [conduct](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct") play opens up several other considerations for using The Platinum Yendorian Express Card:

- For [illiterate](/wiki/Illiterate "Illiterate") conduct players, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is the only method of charging available, particularly for various wands such as the wand of wishing and [wand of death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death").
- Liquid-diet [foodless](/wiki/Foodless "Foodless") players may seek the Card in order to sustain their stock of [nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition")-giving [potions](/wiki/Potion "Potion"), usually by invoking it to recharge a [horn of plenty](/wiki/Horn_of_plenty "Horn of plenty").
- Pacifists are more reliant on wands than most, and will want to wish for it in order to charge essential wands and other objects: wands of [fire](/wiki/Wand_of_fire "Wand of fire") and [lightning](/wiki/Wand_of_lightning "Wand of lightning") for engraving, [teleportation](/wiki/Wand_of_teleportation "Wand of teleportation") wands for escaping, and [The Orb of Fate](/wiki/The_Orb_of_Fate "The Orb of Fate") as an unlimited-use [crystal ball](/wiki/Crystal_ball "Crystal ball") that has no risk of exploding (on top of its valuable defensive properties).
- Eating jewelry as mentioned above can overlap with one or more conducts in other ways (e.g., obtaining resistances for pacifists, or boosting AC for [nudists](/wiki/Nudist "Nudist")).

## History

The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is introduced along with most of the other quest artifacts in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0").

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and earlier versions, including variants based on those versions, the Wizard of Yendor would only steal the quest artifact of your current role with his covetous attack, making the Card a much stronger artifact wish.

## Origin

The artifact's name is derived from the Commodore 64 version of the game *Wizardry*, whose manual states that players start with limited gold because "few adventurers have a Platinum Yendorian Express Card". The name is based off the [American Express](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Express#History_of_card_types "wikipedia:American Express") suite of credit cards - certain types of credit cards are also known as *charge cards*, hence the artifact's ability when invoked. Incidentally, the [tiles](/wiki/Tiles "Tiles") representation of credit cards is modeled after a [Mastercard](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mastercard "wikipedia:Mastercard"), which is a credit card but not a charge card.

## Variants

Some variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions may retain that versions rules for the Wizard of Yendor's artifact theft attack, which affects the viability of The Platinum Yendorian Express Card as an artifact wish.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the Wizard of Yendor follows NetHack 3.4.3 rules for his Amulet-stealing attack, making The Platinum Yendorian Express Card a more enticing artifact wish - however, artifact blast damage is heavily buffed to 8d10 damage (or 6d10 if you have magic resistance), generally requiring the wish to be put off until a character has enough HP to survive the blast.

The charging provided by The Platinum Yendorian Express Card can enable practical long-term use of [lightsabers](/wiki/Lightsaber "Lightsaber") for [Jedi](/wiki/Jedi "Jedi") and other players that unrestrict the skill via [crowning](/wiki/Crowning "Crowning").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is [silvered](/wiki/Silver "Silver") and its [material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(dNetHack\) "Object materials (dNetHack)") is changed to actual [platinum](/wiki/Platinum "Platinum"). Like other quest artifacts in dNetHack, it cannot be obtained by wishing, and can only be found outside the Tourist quest in the appropriate [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones"); however, the Wizard of Yendor's Amulet-stealing attack no longer targets quest artifacts, making it an even more valuable resource for Tourists and a stellar bones find for any other role.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), The Platinum Yendorian Express Card has its [material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(xNetHack\) "Object materials (xNetHack)") changed to platinum as well, but is otherwise unchanged.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), artifact wishing is changed so that any artifact wish after the first has a chance of bringing the artifact's owner with it - in the case of The Platinum Yendorian Express Card, this means that a hostile [Twoflower](/wiki/Twoflower "Twoflower") may generate if it is wished for by another role.

This makes spending a very early wish on the artifact quite a [bad idea](/wiki/Bad_idea "Bad idea") - all the [quest leaders](/wiki/Quest_leader "Quest leader") are significantly buffed and possess [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") and [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), and while Twoflower on his own is not as difficult to defeat as some of the others, he will also have half spell damage, telepathy and magic resistance from carrying the Card.

### SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM details, [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") introduces [the Gourd of Infinity](/index.php?title=The_Gourd_of_Infinity\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "The Gourd of Infinity (page does not exist)"), another quest artifact that can be invoked to charge items - this makes The Platinum Yendorian Express Card somewhat less unique, though it is still the lighter of the two charging artifacts.

## Encyclopedia entry

This is an ancient artifact made of an unknown material. It is rectangular in shape, very thin, and inscribed with unreadable ancient runes. When carried, it grants the one who carries it ESP, and reduces all spell induced damage done to the carrier by half. It also protects from magic missile attacks. Finally, its power is such that when invoked, it can charge other objects.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1502](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/artifact.c#L1502)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/read.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 602](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/read.c#L602)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

The Platinum Yendorian Express Card

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
(   The Platinum Yendorian Express Card   (No tile)
Base item credit card
Affiliation
  • neutral
  • Tourist
  • intelligent
When carried
  • telepathy
  • magic resistance
  • half spell damage
When applied (none)
When invoked
  • charging
Base price 7000 zm
Weight 1

The Platinum Yendorian Express Card, informally PYEC, is the Tourist quest artifact. It is the prize for completing the Tourist quest, and is neutral for wishing purposes. Its base item type is a credit card.

The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is the only vanilla quest artifact whose name is not of the form “The X of [the] Y.”

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
  • 3 Strategy
    • 3.1 Conducts
  • 4 History
  • 5 Origin
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM
    • 6.2 dNetHack
    • 6.3 xNetHack
    • 6.4 EvilHack
    • 6.5 SlashTHEM
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry
  • 8 References

Generation

For Tourists, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is always guarded by the Master of Thieves, and is placed on his square in the northwestern-most room of the Tourist quest goal level.

If the artifact is generated in a bones file that is discovered by a Tourist, it will always be replaced with its mundane base item.

Description

While carried, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card confers magic resistance, telepathy and half spell damage. Invoking the Card can charge objects like a scroll of charging, with different effects based on the Card's beatitude: Tourists can invoke the blessed Platinum Yendorian Express Card to charge objects in the same way as a blessed scroll of charging, while the artifact only charges like an uncursed scroll for non-Tourists.[1] Unlike the scroll, the Card has no special effect if invoked while you are confused.

Strategy

Main article: Invoke#Optimal invocation schedule

The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is considered one of the best artifacts in the game due to its unique invoke, incredibly light weight and valuable properties, making it an enticing and somewhat common artifact wish for neutral players - be sure that you can survive the ensuing artifact blast, and wish for it fireproofed! The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is a powerful aid for various purposes, such as altar farming using a bag of tricks or wand of create monster, or polypiling for certain weapons and/or magical tools - players eating jewelry often use the Card to charge any applicable rings.

Tourists completing their Quest are in a particularly good position, as the Master of Thieves lacks any other resistances beyond stoning resistance and the magic resistance from picking up the Card, making him one of the easier nemeses to defeat. Tourists also get the most out of the artifact by far, and can use blessed charging from the Card's invoke to efficiently recharge their wand of wishing or magic markers where any other role would require a blessed scroll of charging.[2] The artifact also grants more mileage from various wands and certain stat-boosting rings, as well as practically-infinite use of charged tools, without using scrolls or marker charges; this makes uncursed charging and artifact blasts worth dealing with for non-Tourists far more often than not, and can save a lot of inventory space for the weight-conscious player.

With all the above perks in mind, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is a luxury for neutral non-Tourists (albeit an excellent one): they should prioritize wishes that increase survivability where possible, though lucky players (especially ones that get early wishes) may find themselves with a spare wish that can be spent on the Card if so desired. Any role using the Card should have other sources of magic resistance and telepathy available alongside the Card—the Wizard of Yendor can swipe it from you with his Amulet-targeting attack and becomes far more troublesome to deal with if he does, so it is typically a good idea to bag it during the late game and ascension run.

Conducts

Neutral conduct play opens up several other considerations for using The Platinum Yendorian Express Card:

  • For illiterate conduct players, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is the only method of charging available, particularly for various wands such as the wand of wishing and wand of death.
  • Liquid-diet foodless players may seek the Card in order to sustain their stock of nutrition-giving potions, usually by invoking it to recharge a horn of plenty.
  • Pacifists are more reliant on wands than most, and will want to wish for it in order to charge essential wands and other objects: wands of fire and lightning for engraving, teleportation wands for escaping, and The Orb of Fate as an unlimited-use crystal ball that has no risk of exploding (on top of its valuable defensive properties).
  • Eating jewelry as mentioned above can overlap with one or more conducts in other ways (e.g., obtaining resistances for pacifists, or boosting AC for nudists).

History

The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is introduced along with most of the other quest artifacts in NetHack 3.1.0.

In NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions, including variants based on those versions, the Wizard of Yendor would only steal the quest artifact of your current role with his covetous attack, making the Card a much stronger artifact wish.

Origin

The artifact's name is derived from the Commodore 64 version of the game Wizardry, whose manual states that players start with limited gold because "few adventurers have a Platinum Yendorian Express Card". The name is based off the American Express suite of credit cards - certain types of credit cards are also known as charge cards, hence the artifact's ability when invoked. Incidentally, the tiles representation of credit cards is modeled after a Mastercard, which is a credit card but not a charge card.

Variants

Some variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions may retain that versions rules for the Wizard of Yendor's artifact theft attack, which affects the viability of The Platinum Yendorian Express Card as an artifact wish.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, the Wizard of Yendor follows NetHack 3.4.3 rules for his Amulet-stealing attack, making The Platinum Yendorian Express Card a more enticing artifact wish - however, artifact blast damage is heavily buffed to 8d10 damage (or 6d10 if you have magic resistance), generally requiring the wish to be put off until a character has enough HP to survive the blast.

The charging provided by The Platinum Yendorian Express Card can enable practical long-term use of lightsabers for Jedi and other players that unrestrict the skill via crowning.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is silvered and its material is changed to actual platinum. Like other quest artifacts in dNetHack, it cannot be obtained by wishing, and can only be found outside the Tourist quest in the appropriate bones; however, the Wizard of Yendor's Amulet-stealing attack no longer targets quest artifacts, making it an even more valuable resource for Tourists and a stellar bones find for any other role.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, The Platinum Yendorian Express Card has its material changed to platinum as well, but is otherwise unchanged.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, artifact wishing is changed so that any artifact wish after the first has a chance of bringing the artifact's owner with it - in the case of The Platinum Yendorian Express Card, this means that a hostile Twoflower may generate if it is wished for by another role.

This makes spending a very early wish on the artifact quite a bad idea - all the quest leaders are significantly buffed and possess sleep resistance and poison resistance, and while Twoflower on his own is not as difficult to defeat as some of the others, he will also have half spell damage, telepathy and magic resistance from carrying the Card.

SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM details, SlashTHEM introduces the Gourd of Infinity, another quest artifact that can be invoked to charge items - this makes The Platinum Yendorian Express Card somewhat less unique, though it is still the lighter of the two charging artifacts.

Encyclopedia entry

This is an ancient artifact made of an unknown material. It is rectangular in shape, very thin, and inscribed with unreadable ancient runes. When carried, it grants the one who carries it ESP, and reduces all spell induced damage done to the carrier by half. It also protects from magic missile attacks. Finally, its power is such that when invoked, it can charge other objects.

References

  1. ↑ src/artifact.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1502
  2. ↑ src/read.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 602

In [[NetHack 3.4.3]] and earlier versions, including variants based on those versions, the Wizard of Yendor would only steal the quest artifact of your current role with his covetous attack, making the Card a much stronger artifact wish. ==Origin== The artifact's name is derived from the Commodore 64 version of the game ''Wizardry'', whose manual states that players start with limited gold because "few adventurers have a Platinum Yendorian Express Card". The name is based off the [[Wikipedia:American Express#History of card types|American Express]] suite of credit cards - certain types of credit cards are also known as ''charge cards'', hence the artifact's ability when invoked. Incidentally, the [[tiles]] representation of credit cards is modeled after a [[Wikipedia:Mastercard|Mastercard]], which is a credit card but not a charge card. ==Variants== Some variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions may retain that versions rules for the Wizard of Yendor's artifact theft attack, which affects the viability of The Platinum Yendorian Express Card as an artifact wish. ===SLASH'EM=== In [[SLASH'EM]], the Wizard of Yendor follows NetHack 3.4.3 rules for his Amulet-stealing attack, making The Platinum Yendorian Express Card a more enticing artifact wish - however, artifact blast damage is heavily buffed to 8d10 damage (or 6d10 if you have magic resistance), generally requiring the wish to be put off until a character has enough HP to survive the blast. The charging provided by The Platinum Yendorian Express Card can enable practical long-term use of [[lightsaber]]s for [[Jedi]] and other players that unrestrict the skill via [[crowning]]. ===dNetHack=== In [[dNetHack]], The Platinum Yendorian Express Card is [[silver]]ed and its [[Object materials (dNetHack)|material]] is changed to actual [[platinum]]. Like other quest artifacts in dNetHack, it cannot be obtained by wishing, and can only be found outside the Tourist quest in the appropriate [[bones]]; however, the Wizard of Yendor's Amulet-stealing attack no longer targets quest artifacts, making it an even more valuable resource for Tourists and a stellar bones find for any other role. ===xNetHack=== In [[xNetHack]], The Platinum Yendorian Express Card has its [[Object materials (xNetHack)|material]] changed to platinum as well, but is otherwise unchanged. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], artifact wishing is changed so that any artifact wish after the first has a chance of bringing the artifact's owner with it - in the case of The Platinum Yendorian Express Card, this means that a hostile [[Twoflower]] may generate if it is wished for by another role. This makes spending a very early wish on the artifact quite a [[bad idea]] - all the [[quest leader]]s are significantly buffed and possess [[sleep resistance]] and [[poison resistance]], and while Twoflower on his own is not as difficult to defeat as some of the others, he will also have half spell damage, telepathy and magic resistance from carrying the Card. ===SlashTHEM=== In addition to SLASH'EM details, [[SlashTHEM]] introduces [[the Gourd of Infinity]], another quest artifact that can be invoked to charge items - this makes The Platinum Yendorian Express Card somewhat less unique, though it is still the lighter of the two charging artifacts. ==Encyclopedia entry== {{encyclopedia| This is an ancient artifact made of an unknown material. It is rectangular in shape, very thin, and inscribed with unreadable ancient runes. When carried, it grants the one who carries it ESP, and reduces all spell induced damage done to the carrier by half. It also protects from magic missile attacks. Finally, its power is such that when invoked, it can charge other objects. }} ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Quest artifacts|Platinum Yendorian Express Card]]
